titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Maud Allan Papers, 1910-1934 LSC.2038
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Wendy LIttell; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-05-17 13:39:27 -0700.

did.unittitle: Maud Allan papers
did.abstract: Maud Allan (1883-1956) was a interpretive dancer. She made her performing debut in Vienna (1903) and was best known for her solo performance in The vision of Salome (1908). She toured India (1913), Southeast Asia (1913 and 1923), South America (1919-1920), and the U.S. The collection contains manuscripts, photographs, postcard albums, books, ephemera, and a scrapbook related to Allan's life and career.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: PORTIONS OF THIS COLLECTION HAVE BEEN DIGITIZED. Please consult digital facsimiles instead of originals. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Maud Allan Papers (Collection 2038). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Maud Allan was born in Toronto, Canada in 1883; raised in San Francisco, California; performing debut, Vienna, 1903; best known solo performance, The vision of Salome, 1908; toured India in 1913, Southeast Asia in 1913 and 1923, South America from 1919 to 1920, and the U.S.; had a school in England beginning in 1928; died in Los Angeles, October 7, 1956.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection contains manuscripts, photographs, postcard albums, books, ephemera, and a scrapbook related to the life and career of Canadian-born interpretive dancer Maud Allan. Correspondence in a letter book represents correspondence by her agent, W. Angus MacLeod. Some books in the collection were presentation copies made to Allan, while others are from her library. The postcard album is made up of postcards sent to Allan.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
Manuscripts, ephemera, and books (Box 1).
Photograph albums and books (Box 2).
Scrapbook and postcard album (Box 3).

altformavail.head: Online Items Available
altformavail.p: Portions of this collection have been digitized and are available online: Maud Allan Papers (5 items).

did.unittitle: Ephemera
Maud Allan and her art. England
Manuscripts
Letter book of Maud Allan's India and Far East tour. v.p.
did.physdesc: 179 leaves. 25 cm. Carbon copies of holograph correspondence. Bound in grey cardboard cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Most of the correspondence is by her agent, W. Angus MacLeod.

did.unittitle: Presentation Copies to/or Books Owned by Maud Allan
Plays of gods and men; The tents of Arabs; The laughter of the Gods; The queen's enemies; and A night at an inn. New York: G.P. Putnam's Son's [].
Lady precious stream. An old Chinese play done into English according to its traditional style. With a preface by Lascelles Abercrombie. London: Methuen & Company, Limited [].
Rhythm, music and education. Translated from the French by Harold Rubinstein. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons
The sunken bell. A fairy play in five acts. By Gerhart Hauptmann. Freely rendered into English verse by Charles Henry Meltzer. New York: Doubleday, Page & Company [].
Dance as an art form. Its history and development. New York: A.S. Barnes and Company
Margaret Morris dancing. A book of pictures by Fred Daniels. With an introduction and outline of her method by Margaret Morris. London, Kegan Paul, Trench, Trubner & Company, Limited [].
The unchastened woman. A comedy. New York: Frederick A. Stokes, Company [].
Mimes et ballet grecs. Paris: Librairie Léon Vanier, éditeur
Oversize Packages
1 postcard album (several of the postcards are addressed to Maud Allan).
1 scrapbook album (compiled of postcards gathered while on a personal tour of Europe in ).
Photograph Albums
1 album of photgraphs of Maud Allan and friends.
1 album of photographs of Maud Allan and friends in Africa.
1 album of photographs of Maud Allan at grave of Cecil Rhodes.
1 album of photographs of Maud Allan and friends on their India and Far mast tour. Photographs taken by J.W. Mitchell.
